block.p: Milosevic Vows to Summon World Leaders in His Trial Slobodan Milosevic said he would call world leaders to testify in his war crimes trial, including former President Clinton. Mr. Milosevic also said he would personally cross-examine witnesses, including those who were raped, tortured or had their families killed, purportedly by Serbs.

Asylum Seekers Stage Protests Fires and riots raged through Europe's largest immigrant detention center, near Bedford, 50 miles north of London, leaving six people injured, officials said. Some 20 asylum seekers fled, but 10 were recaptured.

China Expels Demonstrators China expelled 33 Americans and 20 other foreigners a day after they were arrested in the largest demonstration yet by foreign members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement, the Beijing police said. The protest on Tiananmen Square came one week before President Bush is to arrive in Beijing on a visit.

Afghan Leader Says Aides Killed a Senior Official Hamid Karzai, chairman of Afghanistan's interim government, said the killing on Thursday of one of his ministers was carried out by other senior government officials, including the intelligence chief.

Cheney Takes Hard Line on Iraq Vice President Dick Cheney said the United States would use all available means to stop Saddam Hussein from developing weapons of mass destruction and he expected allied support if ''aggressive action is required.''

Algerian Asks U.S. to End Case Lotfi Raissi, an Algerian pilot freed on bail after the United States abandoned an effort to extradite him on terrorism charges, appealed to Washington to drop further charges.
Trial Date for American The trial of John Walker Lindh, the Californian captured among the Taliban, was set for late August.
Rebuilding Afghanistan President Bush said a Peace Corps assessment team would leave for Afghanistan within three weeks.

Head of Youth Camp Is Arrested in Boy's Death Charles Long II, who runs a boot camp for troubled youth near Phoenix, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder in the death of a boy at the camp seven months ago. Mr Long, 56, was also charged with child abuse, aggravated assault and possession of marijuana. Two other camp workers were arrested.

Priests Accused of Sex Abuse The bishop of the Diocese of Manchester, which covers all of New Hampshire, announced the names of 14 priests who were accused of sexually abusing children in the past and gave the names to prosecutors.

Court Delays Texas Execution The Supreme Court gave a stay of execution to Thomas Miller-El and agreed to use his case to decide how a defendant can prove that jury selection was unconstitutionally tainted by racial discrimination.

Miss America Takes a Stand Miss America, Katie Harman, professed devotion to her job and to the pageant's organization, which has been roiled by dissent over changes and plans made by its chief executive, Robert M. Renneisen Jr.

Bush Settles on Nuclear Dump President Bush said a 57-year accumulation of nuclear waste from power plants and weapons should be buried in the Nevada desert at Yucca Mountain. The plan must be approved by Congress, the courts and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
Girding for Social Security Fight The House majority leader, Dick Armey, urged fellow Republicans not to shrink from a fight with Democrats over shoring up Social Security.

Hit-and-Run Suspect Says He Also Shot Cab Driver Ronald J. Popadich, who faces charges in two Midtown hit-and-run incidents involving more than two dozen people, admitted to shooting a cab driver on Wednesday, the police said. And one of the injured pedestrians died, raising the possibility that the charges would include murder.

Mayoral Crackdown on Smoking Mayor Bloomberg promised to stop city employees, including police officers, from smoking in public buildings and said he would speak to the commissioner about complaints that some officers and supervisors routinely smoked in station houses, in violation of city regulations.

Canadians Get Gold The Canadian runners-up in the pairs figure-skating competition were awarded gold Olympic medals, an honor they will share with the Russian gold medalists; a French judge was suspended for misconduct.
'War and Peace' Concerns The Met's production, with a cast of hundreds and a rotating set, prompted safety questions after a supernumerary fell into the orchestra pit.

Aid for Smaller Cultural Groups New York City's new commissioner of cultural affairs, Kate D. Levin, said she hoped to restructure her agency's budget to shift more money to some of the city's less-well-known cultural organizations.

Lay's Sales of Enron Stock Kenneth L. Lay sold $100 million in Enron stock last year, with a large part coming from selling shares back to the company after he had been warned by Sherron S. Watkins that the company might collapse ''in a wave of accounting scandals.''

William Lerach, a flamboyant class-action lawyer, was named to represent the lead plaintiff, the University of California, in the tangle of securities fraud cases against Arthur Andersen and former Enron officials.

In letters Mr. Lay wrote to George W. Bush when Mr. Bush was governor of Texas, the former Enron chairman lobbied for his company's pet issue, electric deregulation, sought the governor's presence at Enron-related functions and sent magazine articles and personal notes.

Echoes of the Tech Stock Boom The initial public offering of PayPal, a Silicon Valley company that lets people pay for goods and services online, opened at $13, rose to $22.44 and closed at $20.09, raising $70.2 million.
The Nasdaq fell 2.1 percent; the S.& P. 500 lost 1.1 percent; and the Dow slid nearly 1 percent.
Editorials: Backward on global warming; an insecure Afghanistan; Olympic recount; beware the Asian longhorned beetle.
